sample.title: How Trumpâ€™s Tariffs Are Crushing Small Businesses While Big Retailers Thrive
sample.description:
Small businesses are reeling under the weight of Trump tariffs. Eunice Byun is the CEO of Material Kitchen, a small business that sells kitchenware for the home. She says the complexity of her supply chain has increased tenfold. Anjali Bhargava the owner of Anjaliâ€™s Cup which sells chai concentrate and turmeric blends says the current economic climate along with tariffs are threatening her livelihood. The U.S. has about 36 million small businesses that account for about 99.9% of all U.S. businesses. So what impact are tariffs having on small businesses and how are larger retailers like Walmart and Amazon able to skirt their impact. CNBC spoke with small business owners to find out.

Chapters:
0:00- 2:19 Introduction
2:20 - 5:55 Chapter 1 Mitigating tariffs
5:56 - 8:52 Chapter 2 Tariff impact
8:52 - 11:25 Chapter 3 Large retailers

sample.title: A tangled web of AI deals
sample.description:
The pace and scale of artificial intelligence deals lately has been staggering, with ChatGPT-maker OpenAI alone racking up around $1 trillion-worth of AI deals this year. These interconnected investments have dramatically lifted the valuations of many of the companies involved and sent U.S. stock indexes to new highs.

But some experts are worried that this web of deals is reminiscent of the dotcom bubble.

sample.title: Why Americans Are Suddenly All In On Thrift Clothes
sample.description:
At ThredUp's 600,000-square-foot warehouse in Suwanee, Georgia, roughly 40,000 pieces of used clothing are processed each day. The resale company's logistics network, four facilities across the U.S., now rivals that of some fast-fashion giants. The global secondhand apparel market is expected to reach $367 billion by 2029, growing almost three times faster than the overall global apparel market. For years, Gen Z shoppers have been driving the rise of secondhand fashion. Now, rising prices and new tariffs announced by the White House earlier this year are pushing even more Americans to follow their lead. CNBC got a behind-the-scenes look at ThredUpâ€™s operations to learn more about how new AI tools and tariffs are boosting Americaâ€™s secondhand market.

00:00 Introduction
1:44 ThredUp's resale machine 
3:24 When tariffs hit fashion
5:33 AI and the future of shopping

sample.title: The Truth About AI And The Mass Layoffs
sample.description:
Between January and September 2025, there have been 946,426 job cuts announced, with roughly 300,000 from the government sector, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas. But some economists don't buy that recent layoffs are caused by AI. Economic uncertainty, tariffs and less consumer spending might be hurting U.S. workers more than CEOs will admit.

0:00 Introduction
1:37 Chapter 1: AI washing
3:18 Chapter 2: Cutting corporate bloat

sample.title: Are city-run grocery stores a good idea?
sample.description:
Grocery prices in U.S. urban areas have tripled over the past 40 years, straining household budgets, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Zohran Mamdani, the Democratic winner of New York Cityâ€™s mayoral primary, is proposing city-owned grocery stores to "keep prices low, not make a profit." These are not new concepts in the U.S. and have been tried in the past.

CNBC visited two smaller cities in Kansas to see how this model operates and whether it could be replicated in larger cities.

sample.title: IBM CEO: 'I think quantum today is where AI and GPUs were in 2015'
sample.description:
IBM CEO Arvind Krishna said on Friday that the company is "three to four" years away from their quantum supercomputer solving problems that "amaze us."

Krishna also told CNBC's Sara Eisen that quantum is currently "where AI and GPUs were in 2015."

sample.title: Trump 'looking at' exemption for Hungary on Russian oil sanctions
sample.description:
U.S. President Donald Trump welcomed Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban to the White House for a discussion about Hungary's reliance on Russian oil at a time when Trump has been working to wean nations off of it.
 
Trump said he is "looking at" giving Hungary an exemption on Russian oil sanctions.

sample.title: Transportation secretary says safety data behind move to cut flights
sample.description:
U.S. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy said his department decided not to immediately cut 10% of flights amid the government shutdown because it "could be even more disruptive," instead opting to phase them starting at 4%.
 
Duffy said safety data was behind the move, including incidents of planes not maintaining separation and ground incursions.

sample.title: Stephen Fry and the Godfather of AI | BBC News
sample.description:
Sir Stephen Fry, actor, comedian and recent star of 'Celebrity Traitors', joins the renowned Canadian computer scientist and 'Godfather of AI' Yoshua Bengio.
 
They discuss their shared concern about the development of advanced AI systems. Does the world need a red telephone, as introduced in the nuclear era? What are the dangers of people forming emotional attachments with machines? And where do the solutions lie?
 
This week presenter Christian Fraser is joined by regular host Dr Stephanie Hare.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

sample.title: Elon Musk dances with robot as $1tn pay-deal approved by shareholders. #Tesla #ElonMusk #BBCNews
Is Russia about to take a key Ukrainian city? | BBC Ukrainecast
sample.description:
Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelensky said this week that there are 170,000 Russian troops on the outskirts of Pokrovsk, a logistical hub in the Donetsk region which it has been targeting for more than a year. Meanwhile, on the diplomatic front, some analysts are pointing to Turkeyâ€™s apparent pivot away from Russian oil purchases as evidence that new US sanctions are beginning to bite.

To answer your questions, Lucy Hockings is joined in the Ukrainecast studio by the BBCâ€™s Europe digital editor Paul Kirby and senior digital journalist Laura Gozzi, as well as diplomatic correspondent James Landale from Kyiv. Could Ukraine develop its own nuclear weapons? Will a Swedish aircraft become a gamechanger? And would the seizure of frozen Russian assets held in Belgium really discourage external investment in Europe?

sample.title: "Our justice system's dependent on the honesty of crooks" | BBC Question Time
sample.description:
Prime Minister Keir Starmer says he is "angry and frustrated" over the mistaken release of two prisoners from Wandsworth jail, just a month after another prisoner was accidentally released in Chelmsford. A BBC Question Time audience members asks: "How hard can it be to keep the correct prisoners in prison?", featuring Labour's Anna Turley, Conservative Graham Stuart, Trades Union Congress General Secretary Paul Nowak and journalist Tim Stanley
 
Catch up with the whole of the debate with BBC Question Time on iPlayer and Sounds now.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

sample.title: The Week: Mistaken Prisoner Releases and Tax Rises Are Coming? | BBC Newscast
sample.description:
Today, after another two prisoners were mistakenly released from prison - why is the justice system failing and who is to blame?

Justice Secretary David Lammy is under increasing pressure after details have emerged that two more prisoners have been wrongly released. Why didnâ€™t Mr Lammy explain the situation when he was speaking during PMQs? And what has gone wrong?

Plus, after a week where it has become increasingly clear more tax rises are expected at the budget - what is the chancellorâ€™s plan?

Adam and Chris are joined by the head of the Institute for Fiscal Studies Helen Miller and Luke Tryl from More in Common.
